message.content:
cs.IT, cs.CR, cs.NI, cs.SY, cs.CC. 

The paper deals with the problem of securing a network coding system against an adversary that is both an eavesdropper and a jammer. This suggests that the paper is likely to belong to the Information Theory (cs.IT) sub-category, which deals with the mathematical foundations of information and communication. The paper also considers the problem of achieving zero-error communication that is information-theoretically secure from the adversary, which suggests that it may also belong to the Cryptography and Security (cs.CR) sub-category. The paper deals with network coding, which suggests that it may also belong to the Networking and Internet Architecture (cs.NI) sub-category. The paper proposes a scheme based on rank-metric codes, which suggests that it may also belong to the Systems and Control (cs.SY) sub-category, which deals with the analysis and design of complex systems. Finally, the paper proposes a low-complexity encoding and decoding scheme, which suggests that it may also belong to the Computational Complexity (cs.CC) sub-category, which deals with the study of the inherent difficulty of computational problems.
